title: 109_hr4049
content: The Act is titled the "Early Pest Detection and Surveillance Improvement Act" and aims to support commodity inspection efforts to prevent the introduction or spread of pests. The "Early Pest Detection and Surveillance Improvement Act" defines key terms such as department of agriculture, early pest detection and surveillance, pest, and Secretary. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Agriculture, and the term "State" includes several states, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, Guam, American Samoa, the Northern Mariana Islands, Micronesia, the Marshall Islands, Palau, and the US Virgin Islands. The Secretary of Agriculture is authorized to enter into cooperative agreements with departments of agriculture for early pest detection assistance. The Secretary of Agriculture can enter into cooperative agreements with departments of agriculture for early pest detection and surveillance efforts. Departments of agriculture must submit an application containing required information. The Secretary will notify applicants of auditing and reporting requirements for fund use and criteria for pest detection activities. The cooperative agreement for pest detection and surveillance activities is based on knowledge, experience, and capabilities. It includes identifying pathways of pest introductions and determining support levels for these activities. The Secretary consults with relevant organizations and considers economic risks when entering into agreements with departments of agriculture. The cooperative agreement for pest detection and surveillance activities focuses on economic risks, early detection likelihood, leveraging funds, state agriculture department activities, and complementing federal exclusion efforts. The department of agriculture receiving funds must use them for early pest detection and surveillance to prevent pest introduction or aid in eradication. The Federal share of costs for these activities should not exceed 50 percent, with non-Federal cost sharing required. The non-Federal share of the cost for early pest detection and surveillance activities can be provided in cash or in kind. There is an exception where a Federal share greater than 50 percent may be necessary for underserved areas or critical needs, as determined by the Secretary. A reporting requirement is also mandated within 180 days. The department of agriculture must report on early pest detection activities within 180 days. Funds under this section supplement other assistance for surveillance. Receipt of funds does not affect PILT payments. Authorization of appropriations is provided. Authorization of appropriations is provided for the Secretary for fiscal years 2006 through 2010 to carry out this section, with a limit of five percent for administrative costs.
